div.head: Compendium Belli: OR THE TOVCHSTONE of Martiall Di≈øcipline.
Principall and e≈øpeciall Rules for euery Commaunder to be perfect in.
div.p: THo≈øe things that helpeth the Enemie greatly, annoyeth thee, and the ≈øame that helpeth thee, hurteth him.

Hee that is more carefull and vigelant, to ob≈øerue the cunning and polliticke deui≈øes of the Enemy, and al≈øo taketh mo≈øt paines in the exerci≈øing his Company, or Army, ≈øhall be ≈øure to incurre lea≈øt perills, and may haue greate≈øt hope of victorie.
Neuer enterpri≈øe any dangerous incounter with thy Souldiers, but fir≈øt by thy pollicie, let there be giuen out, hope of victorie.
It is better to conq ‚Ä¢ er the Enemy with famine, then with the ≈øword; in the victory of which, fortune may doe much more then valoure.
No plot or purpo≈øe is better then that which is hid from the Enemy, vntill it be executed.
To know in the warre how to vnder≈øtand occa≈øion, and take it, more auayleth then any thing.
Nature breedeth few ≈øtrong and valient men, but indu≈øtry and exerci≈øe maketh many.
Di≈øcipline may doe much more in time of battell, then furie.

If any of the Enemies Souldiers depart from them and fly to thee (≈øo they prooue faythfull) they ≈øhall be allwaies vnto thee great gaines, and ≈øtand thee in great ≈øteede, for that the power of thy Enemies are thereby demini≈øhed, and much more weakened, then of tho≈øe that be ≈ølaine, though the name of a Fugitiue be to old frinds odious, to new ≈øu≈øpected.
Better it is in pitching the field, to re≈øerue behinde the fir≈øt front ayde enough, then to make a big front, which will doe great hurt, and di≈øper≈øe the Companies.
He is difficultly ouercome, which knoweth his owne ≈øtrength, and the power of his enemies.
The valour of the Souldiers, more auaileth then the multitude.
Sometimes the ≈øituation helpeth more then valour.

New & ≈øodaine thinges make Armies affraide; ≈ølowe and accu≈øtomed things be little regarded: Therefore make thy Armie practi≈øe; and know, with ≈ømall fightes a new enemy, before thou aduentere≈øt to fight a field with them.
He that with di≈øorder followeth the enemie after that their order is broken, will become of a Conquerour a Conquered.
He that prepareth not nece≈ø≈øary victualls, with all manner of Amunition, is ouercome without the Sword.
He that tru≈øteth more in Foote-men then Hor≈øe-men, or in Hor≈øe-men more then in Foote-men, mu≈øt accomodate him≈øelfe with the ≈øituation.
When thou would≈øt ≈øee if in the day there be come any Spie into the Campe, make proclamation that euery man goe to his lodging, ≈øo ≈øhall you know your owne men from ≈øtrangers.
Change purpo≈øe if thou perceiue≈øt that thy enemie hath fore≈øeene it.
Con≈øult with many aboute the thinges thou oughte≈øt to doe, the ≈øame thou wilt after doe, conferre with few.
Souldiers when they abide at home, are mainteyned with feare and puni≈øhment; after, when they are led to the warre, with hope and rewarde.

Be ≈øure the enemie know not how thou wilt order thy Army in battell; and what≈øoeuer manner
≈øets the battell, make that the fir≈øt Bande be receiued off fir≈øt and ≈øecond.
In fight neuer occupie the battell to any other thing then to the ≈øame for which thou ha≈øt appointed it, if thou meane≈øt to make no di≈øorder.
Suddaine accidents are remedyed with difficulty, tho≈øe that are thought vpon with facility.

Before thou bringe≈øt thy Souldiers to giue battell, cau≈øe them to be ranged in forme of battell, making of his Foote-men ≈øundry Battalions, and of tho≈øe ≈øundry fronts; to deuide the Hor≈øe-men al≈øo in ≈øundry troopes, placing the Lances, Light-hor≈øemen, and Hargubu≈øiers, euery front in ≈øeuerall troupes by them≈øelues, to cau≈øe the forlorne to i≈ø≈øue out, and skirmi≈øh them before the battalions, as if the enemy were indeed pre≈øent, and vpon a retreate ≈øounded and beaten, ≈øuddenly to retire: The Hor≈øe-men to charge, and ≈øuddenly to returne againe into their place; vpon their retreate to cau≈øe certaine ≈øleeues of Pikes, and light armed, to runne out to their reskew, as though the enemie did pur≈øue them: Then the Battalions of the fir≈øt front to march forward, and charge the enemie, and ≈øuddenly after the ≈øound of the retreate, to retire them≈øelues orderly, betweene the Battalions of the ≈øecond front: Then the ≈øecond front mu≈øt charge, and march forward together with the other that la≈øt retired, and make head together vpon the enemy.

La≈øt of all, the light armed Foote-men and
Hor≈øe-men mu≈øt i≈ø≈øue out, as it were to doe execution vpon the enemie.

Whil≈øt fayre weather is, the Generall mu≈øt acquaint the Souldiers to ≈øleepe vpon bare ground: Although the enemy be farre ab≈øent, yet duely to mainteine the Skoutes, lay out their Pardues, ≈øet forth their Centryes, and performe all manner of Millitary Orders, as curiou≈øly and carefully as if the enemie were pre≈øent: He mu≈øt keepe his Souldiers in continuall exerci≈øe; and by feigned Allarums, to ≈øee in what readine≈ø≈øe his Forces would be (if nece≈ø≈øity required:) But if the enemie chance to cau≈øe any Allarum indeede, it is his pollicie then to cau≈øe the Campe to be in armes by the ≈øound only of the Drumbe≈øtickes, or ≈øome other priuate watch-word, or ≈øome Warning-peece, which when the enemie perceiues that the Campe is in Armes without any manner of Allarum, will much amaze and terrify them, to finde them in ≈øuch readine≈ø≈øe, daring them and their affronts.

Al≈øo, the Generall ought to ≈øhew them all manner of wayes how the enemie may attempt them, di≈øcouering al≈øo to them their remedy, and how they are to an≈øwere to tho≈øe attempts; for no Man is borne a Souldier, but by exerci≈øe and indu≈øtry it is attayned, and by di≈øcontinuance againe it is lo≈øt, as all other Artes and Sciences are.

You mu≈øt haue a ≈øpeciall care, that the Army haue not in their faces the du≈øt to blinde them, the winde to di≈øturbe them, or the Sunne beames to annoy them, before they enter into any maine Encounter; the which Impediments, not only altogether, but each one by him≈øelfe alone, doth bring great toyle, trouble, and di≈øaduantage.

figure.head: The forme of ≈øeuerall Marches.

div.p: IF you meane to exerci≈øe a Company, you mu≈øt bring them into this forme. viz. The Muskatiers mu≈øt be placed on both ≈øides of the Pikes, fiue Files on one ≈øide, and fiue on the other, the Pikes ten deepe, and ≈øo many ≈øquare in the middle.

div.head: To your Right Hand.
div.p: Fir≈øt note, that before you begin to exerci≈øe the Company, you fir≈øt commaund them to aduance their Pikes, and to ≈øhoulder their Muskets: Then you haue no more to doe, but to cau≈øe them to turne to their Right-hand, which is thus; They mu≈øt not remooue their Left legge from the ground, but turue vpon it, and remooue only the Right, to make the Right hand File the Front, as you ≈øee in this Figure.

div.head: As you were.
div.p: As you turned to your Right, ≈øo in the ≈øame manner you mu≈øt turne backe to your Left, keeping your Left legge ≈øtill vpon the ground, vntill you come euen with the Front.

div.head: To the Left Hand.
div.p: Becau≈øe the Enemy may ≈øometimes Charge on the Left Hand Flanke; Therefore, that you may be ≈øudainely ready to defend your ≈øelues, and offend them; and for diuers rea≈øons be≈øides, this Motion is v≈øed: And to doe it, you mu≈øt mooue with your Right Foote, vntill your Faces front toward the Left Flanke, your Left Foote not moouing from the place where it ≈øtood before, but turning.

div.head: As you Were.
div.p: Then hauing performed the afore≈øaid Motion, the Captaine commaunds, As you weare, and then they mooue all towards the Right Hand, vntill they are turned to the fir≈øt Front, moouing vpon the ≈øame Foote you did before.

div.head: To the Right Hand About.
div.p: This Motion is v≈øed, when the Enemy doth Charge in the Reare; then keepe your Left Foote ≈øtill, and turne to the Reare, and Charge, or otherwi≈øe for exerci≈øe.

div.head: To the Left Hand as you were.
div.p: Hauing performed the former Motion, the Captaine commaunds them, To the Left hand as you were, the Left Foote remaines fixed, vntill their faces be turned to the former front.

div.head: To the Left Hand about.
div.p: Sometimes it is more conuenient to turne to the Left Hand then to the Right, therefore this Motion is v≈øed, the Left Legge ≈øtill ≈øtanding.

div.head: To the Right hand as you were.
div.p: It is but turning towards your Right Hand, vntill you come to the former Front.

div.head: Rankes to your Right Hand Double.
div.p: This Motion is onely v≈øed, to double and ≈øtrengthen the Front; and thus it is done, all in the ≈øecond Ranke, march vp in the fir≈øt; and fir≈øt, they mu≈øt ≈øet forward the Right Legge, and then the Left, making but two Paces to the Front, and ≈øo the Fourth, the Sixth, the Eight, and Tenth Ranke, mu≈øt likewi≈øe doe all at one in≈øtant.

div.head: Rankes to your Left Hand as you were.
div.p: Hauing performed the former Motion, you turne about at the Word of Commaund, and ≈øet forward your Left Foote, and ≈øo make two Paces, comming into your forme againe, all at one in≈øtant.

div.head: Rankes to your Left Hand double.
div.p: This is almo≈øt all one as you did with the Right, ≈øaue you mu≈øt ≈øet forward your Left Leg fi ‚Ä¢ ≈øt, and put your ≈øelfe on the Left Hand of your Leader.

div.head: Rankes to your Right Hand as you were.
div.p: You mu≈øt fir≈øt t ‚Ä¢ rne to your Right, becau≈øe you will come the better into your place; and then ≈øet forward your Right Foote, it is more ≈øeemely and Souldier like by much then any other way.

Becau≈øe you ≈øee there is an odde File of Muskatiers, you mu≈øt place the Muskatiers all to the Right Flanke, and it is ea≈øely donne thus, cau≈øing the Left Wing to ≈øtand ≈øtill, and the re≈øt to mooue one pace forwards; then the word of Commaund is; Left Flanke to the Right Hand, and march through thy Files, which with ea≈øe is to be done.

div.head: Files to your Right Hand double.
div.p: There is occa≈øion ≈øometimes to ≈øtrengthen the Flankes, and then they v≈øe this word of Commaund, which is no more to performe then this, if it be to the Right Hand; then the Right Flanke ≈øtandeth ≈øtill, and the next File doubleth it, that is, fall iu≈øt behinde his Side-man, in File with him; Then the Third, Fifth, Seuenth, and euery other ≈øtands: Remember that you mu≈øt make them doe it all at one motion together.

div.head: Files as you were.
div.p: All tho≈øe that doubled, returne into their proper places, by ≈øetting their left Legge fir≈øt to pace: Remember when you double to your right hand, you put your right Legge forward, and when on the left, your left Legge, and ≈øo backwards.

div.head: Files to your Left Hand double.
div.p: This motion differeth little from the other, ≈øaue that the left flancke doe ≈øtand ≈øtill, and the Second doubles it in this action; in doubling the left Legge, goeth to double, and the right comming backe.

div.head: Files as you were.
div.p: Is iu≈øt as the other was, ≈øaue they fall backe to the right hand, with the right legge.

Hauing performed the doubling of Files, which was don with the Shot in the Right Hand Flanck of the Pikes: Now you mu≈øt place them as they were before, one halfe on the Right Flancke, the other on the Left of the Pikes.

div.head: Halfe Files to your Right Hand, Double your Rankes.
div.p: This mu≈øt be done by the ≈øixt Rancke, and you mu≈øt doe it at ten Paces thus; Fir≈øt with your Right Leg ≈øet forward, you mu≈øt March forward, and aduance your Ground towards the Front, all the Rancke ob≈øeruing the Right Hand Leader, and ≈øo mooue altogether to the Front, with whom you mu≈øt Ranke; ob≈øeruing likewi≈øe that when you thus begin to double, you Aduance your Pikes, & when you haue doubled the Front, Order your Pikes, the Sixt mu≈øt rancke with the Fir≈øt, the Seuenth with the Second, the Eight with the Third, and ≈øo all the re≈øt.

When you haue performed the former Motion, they mu≈øt turne to the Right Hand, which is more gracefull and comely, with the Right Foote ≈øet forward, and ≈øo Retreate to the Reare, at ten Paces more, ob≈øeruing your Left Hand, and then you will be tenn deepe againe as you were.

div.head: Halfe Files to your Left Hand, Double your Rankes.
div.p: There is no difference, but onely that the halfe Files mu≈øt march vp to the Left Hand of the Files that ≈øtand.

div.head: Halfe Files to the Right Hand, As you were.
div.p: The halfe Files aduance their Pikes, and falles back with their Right Legge, to be cleare of their Side-men, & ≈øo march into their proper places.

div.head: Files to your Right hand Countermarch.
div.p: When a Charge is expected in the Reare, and it being thought conuenient to haue the Leaders of the Files in the places of the bringers vp, becau≈øe they are men be≈øt able to receiue the Enemie. The Leaders aduancing with their Right Legge turned to the Right Hand, and march downe towards the Reare, all the body of the Company, mouing together: for when the fir≈øt Filers turne, the Second aduanceth in their places, and doth the like, and ≈øo Third, Fourth, and Fifth, &c. There is al≈øo another kinde of Countermarch, which is called the Lacedemonian Countermarch, which is for the Fir≈øt Rancke to Face towards the Reare; the Second, and all the re≈øt of the Body to March vp, and turne behinde their Leaders, you may Countermarch likewi≈øe by Ranckes as you doe by Files.

div.head: Files to your Right Hand Countermarch.
div.p: This motion differeth nothing in the world from the other, for you mu≈øt turne vp on the ≈øame Hand againe, and aduance with the Left Legge, and turne to the Right Hand, and then you March iu≈øt in the place you were in before.

div.head: Clo≈øe your Files both wayes at a Foote and Halfe.
div.p: If a Charge of Hor≈øe bee expected, then the Foote are to be in the clo≈øe≈øt Order, which is one Foote and a Halfe in File, and there in Rancke.

div.head: Clo≈øe your Ranckes to three Foote.
div.p: Which is nothing el≈øe, but to Pace on to the Sword point, which is the iu≈øt di≈øtance of Three Foote,

div.head: Ranckes to the Right Hand wheele.
div.p: If the Enemie Charge on the Right Hand Flancke, to receiue them with the mo≈øt able men which are commonly in the Front, it may be thus performed; the Leader of the Right Hand File ≈øtandeth fixed, onely turning his body, and the re≈øt moue vpon him as the Centre, ob≈øeruing ≈øtill the di≈øtance and ≈øtraightne≈ø≈øe of their Rancks and File, without which, this motion will not be performed gracefully.

div.head: Rancks to your Left Hand wheele.
